reviewText:
Kinda like a FPS Pac Man
This is another one of them little time killers ! The game is like Pac man and the movie The Running Man lol You need to run around blasting all that moves or blast anything in your way. You then collect the orbs White Points , Green Health and Red Rockets.

The Dev or Devs are still adding and Tweaking it atm but it runs pretty sweet as is. I think for the $0.99 cents price tag this is one you might want to pick up and im sure in time they will add more but if not its fun as is .

So for the pirce i say pick this up if you are a fan of cheap neat games or what i like to call time killers!

reviewText:
Alright, so I'm no writer or anything but I like voicing my opinion when I find good games, and this, is a great game.

PROS:
1. Cheap
2. Fun
3. Great for non gaming pc's
4. Lightweight download
5. Unlimited Ammo
6. Ability to slow down time
7. Rage inducing (which I personally like in a game)
8. Distructable enviroment

CON:
1. No Invert mouse option
2. No in game menu
3. No weapon shop or costumability
4. No Multiplayer
5. No Multiple game modes, some would be Survival, Hardcore, Multiplayer, Team Deathmatch, and others, I understand that this is not a FPS game like Call Of Duty or Battlefield, but I really do love this game and I think it would be more fun with these options.

So, if you like a game like Call of Duty, Counter Strike: Global Offensive, or Battlefield, then this is not the game for you, but if you like simple fun games that you can just hop on and play, then this is the game for you... :D

reviewText:
Showtime 2073 is an odd mix of old school FPS and Pacman. We play as a nameless protagonist as he picks up a certain amount of pellet each round all while being chased by tons of astronaut looking fellows out to beat the crud out of you as the crowd cheers on. No explanations for anything is given, just press enter to start the game and take too long to question just what is going on and you'll get karate chopped into oblivion. You can take up to 5 hits from these human enemies and while not threatening at all on their own they do come in large numbers so it is rather easy to take a hit while distracted on the pellets. Regardless of their numbers you will still have a massive advantage in the form of a laser gun with infinite ammo or recharging. You could literally hold the fire button down from the beginning of the game until the end with no side effects like kick back,overheating or anything you'd expect from an FPS.

While the guns and combat do lack any sense of hard hitting impact the human enemies do have ragdoll physics which make it very entertaining to blast through hordes of them. For some reason the developers added a rather absurdly annoying feature that slows the game down after shooting killing an enemy. I honestly thought I was experiencing unusual slowdown as it persisted even when I turned down all the settings but it was in fact a “feature”. With the amount of enemies you'll be shooting down at any given time this slowdown will be active for most of the game which just makes the game feel awkward and sluggish. Along with your trusty gun you'll also have access to 10 rockets for each red pellet you collect. Everything in this game is destructible which is a big plus as you can simply blow up the mazes instead of searching for an exit while the enemies close in on you. Or you can even use it to blow up the cheering crowd that will never seize to amuse me.

As cool as blowing stuff up is it can also come back to haunt you as you may blow a hole straight through the floor, forget about it and fall to your demise later on if you aren't paying attention. There are no other forms of attacking or weapons so it can get old rather quickly. You can jump rather high though you jump just low enough to not be able to go over walls. I find jumping to be a rather pointless thing to do as enemies can and will treat you like as a volley ball in a inescapable chain. Physics are very floaty while in air and  it is not rare that an attack will send you several feet up into the air and cost you most of your life on landing since there is fall damage. Sprinting is the only time you won't be able to shoot though the time between sprinting and being able to shoot is nearly non-noticeable meaning you can easily blast someone just a few feet in front of you. The focus of this game is not really on the combat but collecting the pellets. No matter how many enemies you take down more will spawn in and you will never have time to stop moving.

New enemies such as spiders and mechs make there way into the game later on which are not all that threatening. Your main threat in this game will be the electrical fence at the corners of the levels. They kill you so fast that it leaves little time to escape and is the main reason you don't jump as your doomed if an enemy knocks you into it. It is a pretty unnecessary addition honestly and can very easily be mistaken for any other wall. Some from a shock that still damages you but also repulses you away would have been a better implementation for this hazard. The electrical fence is the only hazard in the game so you've only the enemies to worry about if stay away. Some levels have 100 pellets to collect while others are more arena based and requires you to collect only 10 but has an absolute ton of enemies after you. The green pellets that restore your health are usually the ones you'll want to collect only when you must in case you need them later while on a arena map.

One thing you'll want to change before starting the game is the key bound to closing the game. It is set to the Escape key by default while pausing the game is Tab. The rest of the controls are perfectly fine and work like any other FPS out there. This does feel much more old school than it does like a modern FPS. While you do move slow until sprinting, you can jump rather high,have no iron sights and have a health bar to worry about instead of the usual regenerating health. Shame this game doesn't feature any other modes other than going through the five levels as a simple survival type mode would be a pretty fun addition where you can enjoy the ragdoll physics and destruction without worrying about pellets. A mode such as this would make this a great title to blow off steam. As it is though every time you start the game you'll have to go through all the levels again to reach the mechs, spiders and turrets which can quickly get tiresome. While Showtime 2073 has some rather serious flaws and will get old fast it should be kept in mind that it is priced at two dollars. Go in expecting cheap, mindless fun and you will likely get your moneys worth as you laugh at some poor bloke that fell through a hole right before being falcon punched right down there yourself.

reviewText:
SHOWTIME 2073
Platform: PC
MSRP: $0.99
Link to Lair Gaming's video review: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BMmHRHvU4DA&feature=gp-n-y&google_comment_id=z12gtzd50wvwhd2yv04ccxrqoximyv3prso0k

Welcome to the Lair Gaming review of PACMAN: RELOADED! Wait, no, that's not right. Oh, yeah - SHOWTIME 2073.

Showtime 2073 without a doubt draws inspiration from the aforementioned yellow dot-gobbler. Armed with what almost feels like a fully automatic version of the flak cannon from Unreal Tournament - you are tasked with collecting a number of round orbs from a maze-like map while assaulted from all angles by robots highly trained in martial arts. Has this caught your interest? It probably should.

Gameplay in Showtime 2073 not only looks like Unreal Tournament - it lives and breathes like it too. Running is a little floaty - and the fact that sprinting isn't a persistent feature leaves you constantly having to press and hold shift after each shot or jump. This sounds really nitpicky, but I honestly don't remember a circumstance where I didn't want to be sprinting - so having the default movement speed at sprint level would have been nice here. In addition, jumping was a frustrating affair on occasion. I would find myself trying to jump over portions of wall and getting stuck atop while enemies piled up on either side below. The engine was somehow unable to handle me riding the top of the wall and eventually would choose a direction to roll me off. In addition to some complaints regarding movement - I also wish there was some kind of impact sound or hit marker to show that you landed shots on your targets - but with the hectic movement and need to spray and pray" to survive
date: I understand that there isn't really room for this nitpick to be completely satisfied. Lastly
recommended: I wish there was an option to disable the frequent slow-mo that comes when you kill enemies in quick succession. After a while
hoursPlayed: I did get used to it - and there were even some times I felt thankful for it when I was surrounded by enemies.\n\nIn my almost 3 hours with SHOWTIME 2073 to date
voteText: I've managed to get to level 5 a couple of times - but I've yet to finish it. The difficulty really ramps up when you hit level 4 and the game doesn't save your progress when you close the application (which is done by pressing the escape key - I learned accidentally). Luckily
helpfulPercent: deaths only take you back to the beginning of the current level rather than the beginning of the game.\n\nSHOWTIME's soundtrack is wild. It's just a nonstop
votesHelpful: body-shakingly loud bass attack throughout. I never got tired of it
votesTotal: but this just isn't music I'd be listening to in my spare time. That said
votesFunny: when my heart was racing - the heavy beat became the perfect track.\n\nVisually
commentsCount: you're not going to feel like you're playing a game you paid sub-$1.00 for. The visuals are crisp and remind me of all of my favorite arena shooters. There aren't a ton of assets used in total. Weapon fire always looks the same and environments don't vary all that much. Still
column17: SHOWTIME 2073 delivers. Enemy variety is an excellent way that the developer knew his audience. I counted 5 total enemy types. It doesn't seem like much
column18: but for the price - I honestly expected a single enemy type for every level.\n\nSHOWTIME 2073 did make me want to go back and play Unreal Tournament 2004 again - but most importantly
column19: it made me want to put that off a little while longer so I could stay in the task at hand. This game is so much fun - and I wholly recommend it when you have a spare dollar in your Steam account from selling old trading cards in the market. OK
column20:
maybe that's just the story of me finding this hidden gem.

Gameplay - 78
Visuals/Art Style - 73
Audio - 72
Content-to-cost at $0.99 - 90

For what it's worth
column21: I give SHOWTIME 2073 on PC a: 78/100."

reviewText:
8/10 Would watch to quench futuristic bloodthirst
The game makes you feel as if you're a simple man (Most likely named Daniel Matrixx or sth) that was framed and forced to contest in a Sunday Night gameshow on a psychotic cyberpunk future; and  it is amazing.

Half naked women dance in glass cages while running dudes with spikes in their hands, autoturrets and the terminator-like machine that couldn't do stairs in Robocop try to kill you as you run around and blow ♥♥♥♥ up.

+Fantastic time killer.
+Great fun/price ratio; totally worth buying.

-Minor bugs, nothing too serious.

If you're a fan of blockbuster futuristic utopia movies of the late 80's and early 90's you will love it.

Ps: You may find yourself going Blaagh

reviewText:
I played this game for about a hour.
I went upto level 3, then hit 'Esc' key by mistake, and the game closed.
When i opened it backup there were no saves for this game, so i had to begin from the start.

Pros:
The game is very much fun
Procedureally generated game

Cons:
No Pause game menu
No save system, atleast a levelwise save system would have been sufficient
Only 5 music, which repeats on loop the entire game
The Electrified fence takes out lots of your health on contact, resulting in a irritating experience.


For a game which costs <2$ it's worth your time, and the Developer has promised a Update, so that's a good thing

reviewText:
Normally I would stay away from first-impressions, but until some major content is added in (as well as tweaks to annoying mechanics) I can't recommend you buy this game even at its low price. With some improvements and additional content, SHOWTIME could become the addicting arcade hybrid of Painkiller and Pac-Man it wants to be.

Disclaimer: This is a review copy supplied by the developer to ProGGaming.

Another Unity Asset Game?
I know Unity has been heavily criticized for a lot of schlock on Steam when it's not the engine's fault. Nor am I implying that any game that uses bought assets can never make something interesting. However, and this is only speculation, the game does feel like an asset-flipped game. (For example, the cyberpunk enemies combined with the other assets like the spheres and dancing girls.)

That is the quality I would describe SHOWTIME 2073 overall. Outside of the weird sphere visuals with the rest of the game's visuals, this thought occurred to me when I booted up the game. Also it had a Unity styled launcher with settings like Graphics: Good
recommended: Fantastic."\n\nFor a $1 game that focuses more on its novelty
hoursPlayed: I don't think the visuals are an issue. My problem is that it doesn't do enough with its gimmick to make something that should otherwise be addicting.\n\nIt Talks the Talk
voteText:
But Doesn't Waka the Waka
The game's general description is that it's Pac-Man with guns. That description is misleading because the game is missing many core mechanics that appeal to those types of gamers.

The biggest missing feature from Pac-Man is a scoring system. Nor are there extra lives
votesHelpful: or overpowered bonuses to one-up the enemy. Without those arcade-style features
votesTotal: the game feels like dull with its five same levels.\n\nIncluding a scoring-system
commentsCount: would go a long way to make the gameplay more intresting. For example
column16:
if the game went for something like Bulletstorm where it focuses on flashy combination of kills it would demand more skill of the player to round up enemies for a massive score. Or if the game took a cue from Robot Roller-Derby Disco Dodgeball with its arcade style mode that gave you power-ups--and one life--it would make dying more of a punishment and the score-system more valuable.

SHOWTIME doesn't need to take all its inspiration from Pac-Man. Challenge modes with specific challenges (like with the Binding of Isaac) would also give the game immense replay value. Or maybe the game needs more than one objective to spice it up.

That aspect of the game is just one area for improvement. The other aspect
column18:
could also use a little more effort too.

Where's the Bunny Hop?
Perhaps I'm mistaken that the game is  going for a hybrid of Pac-Man and an old-school FPS
column19: but if the gameplay took a lot more inspiration from old-school FPS conventions it'd make the combat provide a lot more tactical options. The old-school vibe comes from having to pick up health and ammo from the ground like Wolfenstein 3D as well as how you sprint very fast and can jump quite high.\n\nIf the game wasn't going for that route
column20: then it's not a farfetched suggestion to consider for improvement. The tactics/mechanics found in old-school FPSs for health and weapons could be applied here.\n\nFor example
column21: you can launch yourself into the air with rockets--or when enemies hit you--but the health lost is way too high to make that viable. You can't "bunny-hop" to gain momentum to avoid some encounters but you can certainly leap over walls and enemies. Weirdly
column22: the white-orbs do not provide any health bonuses--something I think should be added (only about 1 - 5%) to balance enemies dealing 20% damage with each hit--which would otherwise make them more important to collect.\n\nIt also goes without saying that this game could use a LOT more enemy and weapon variety. But these weapons should be gameplay changers that require a different approach with each weapon (i.e. a shotgun should be used differently than an assault rifle). Enemies should be balanced to suit these new weapons
column23:
and maybe various ammo types could be added to make sure players don't spam rockets.

Nitpicks
The biggest threat in this game is not the mech suits--which I don't know if they can be killed--nor swarms of spiders. It's actually the electrified fence because every attack does 20% damage of health
column24: so you will die in less than 5 seconds if you hug the wall.\n\nThis game could use some procedural generated maps if there will only be five total. Currently
column25: there are only two variants:  Maze-like areas with destructible walls with 100 orbs followed by big open arena with an absurd amount of enemies but only 10 orbs to collect.\n\nWhen you sprint
column26: do not fire your rockets: The rocket will fire from where your gun-model is angled
column27: which can blow open the floor beneath you and you'll fall to your death.\n\nSome various environments would add a lot
column28:
even if it's a day-night change of the map that would go a long way.

More than one background track would also be appreciated.

Space out the difficulty curve better by adding in more maps to both add more content to the game as well as make the challenge fair. The current difficultly is too unfair as new enemy hordes are just thrown at you:  LV 1
column33: Turrets and Mecs in Maze; Lv 4
column36: Turrets and Spiders in Arena; and Lv 5 (as far as I could go
column37:
all the above in a maze.

A save-and-quit option would be nice.

Don't automatic start levels. The enemy AI will always start ahead of you and it adds to needless deaths. Have a "Press Any Key to continue" screen after showing the level's stats.

Very flat levels with no verticality.

Weapons can get "stuck" firing
column38: which leads to blowing holes all over the place with the rocket.\nCheck Back in A Month or Two for Improvements\nThe developer has stated he will be adding in more content in two week intervals. Although this game is not labeled Early Access
column39: many of the suggestions listed on the "future updates" page and the bare-bone gameplay we have now ultimately make the game feel like you're playing one. Perhaps I'm too optimistic but I think this game will improve down the line.\n\nAs a reminder
column40: a lot of these ideas in this review are suggestions for improvement
column41: They are critical about what the game fails to do with its novelty: A Pac-Man FPS or an objective-based old-school shooter. Unlike some other Survival Crafting #30457 Early Access game
column42: the core gameplay is a solid foundation and it has potential (if it's used properly)."

reviewText:
TL; DR: This game is Blue Sphere special Stage from Sonic 3 with lasers.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B0yKuLopp8c

This game is probably one of the more better games from the Dollar Bin.

However, it gets incredibly repetative. Your average run of the mill enemey takes one shot to take down. Not much of a challenge. The game knows this and as levels increase they just add more gimmicks; Robots who don't die. Spiders for some reason and turrets. None of which are challenging, but more annoying then anything.

Any level that is an even number (2,4,6...) was probably the most enjoyable. These stages are large and open and only have 10 balls to collect which is nice enough. In exchange it just spawns baddies at an increased rate.On any odd stage you have to navigate a maze and collect 100 balls, green ones give health red ones are rockets."

These rockets aren't really rockets and the game even refers to them as Mines at one point. They explode and thats enough.

I wish we could get a "Meh" rating. This entertained me for about half an hour and I'm probably not going to play it ever again. But
date: I support indie developers and would like to see more if it can get even better than this."

This game is probably one of the more better games from the Dollar Bin.

However, it gets incredibly repetative. Your average run of the mill enemey takes one shot to take down. Not much of a challenge. The game knows this and as levels increase they just add more gimmicks; Robots who don't die. Spiders for some reason and turrets. None of which are challenging, but more annoying then anything.

Any level that is an even number (2,4,6...) was probably the most enjoyable. These stages are large and open and only have 10 balls to collect which is nice enough. In exchange it just spawns baddies at an increased rate.On any odd stage you have to navigate a maze and collect 100 balls, green ones give health red ones are rockets."

These rockets aren't really rockets and the game even refers to them as Mines at one point. They explode and thats enough.

I wish we could get a "Meh" rating. This entertained me for about half an hour and I'm probably not going to play it ever again. But
date: I support indie developers and would like to see more if it can get even better than this."

reviewText:
Things I shouted when I was playing this game: (3 family members where harmed while I was playing)
STOP SHOOTING HOLY CHRIST!"-Reacting to autofire glitch
"So you just aim for their sides?"-Reacting to how damn simple this game is
"I would really like to eat some green balls right now"-Low health
"OHHHHMYYYYLOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOORDHOOOOOOOOLYJEEEEEEEEEESUUUUUUUUS"-Autofire rocket glitch
"THAT GUY IS A NINJA HOLY LORD!"-Getting roundhoused in the face while in mid air
"There is a HOLE IN THE GROUND!"-Reacting to destructible surfaces
"BURN IT TO THE GROUND!"-Me destroying dead ends and other stuff
"EAT MY RED BALLS YOU NINJAS!"-Rockets
"No wonder this is te best show right now this is really entertaining!"-My positive review
A few weeks later I play it again and only my mother was complaining this time
"MOM I AM PLAYING SHOWTIME 2069 OR 2075 WHATEVER IT WAS CALLED LEAVE ME ALONE"-My poor mother dealing with me
"HOLY LORD I FORGOT HOW LOUD THE MUSIC WAS"-No music setting
"AAJEESSUUS"-Getting roundhoused across the map out of nowhere
"STOP RUBBING YOUR BALLS ON ME DEAD ROBOT NINJA PERSON MAN"-Getting stuck on a corpse
"I WAS SOOOOO CLOSE TO FINALLY MAKING IT PAST LEVEL ONE NOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO!!!!!!!!!"-When I try my best but I don't succeed.
"There is a ROCK stuck in my ♥♥♥!"-Getting stuck on debris
"Mr Develeper gaem creator guy person buddy man please help me out here"-My revised and edited review"

reviewText:
This is a neat little game , it has the core mechanics of a fun game

+ great soundtrack
+ innovative mechanics(fps pacman vibe)
+ Destructive enviroment
+ Quick burst gameplay gives great replayablity
+ Great charactor animations


Things i would personally try fix if i was the developer:

- FPS sometimes jumps way down
- Change the balls to something else they seem a bit off in the enviroment
- The terrain of destruction gets in the way making you not be able to run sometimes.
- 2nd level seems a bit bare

Altogether id say a solid 7.5/10 pretty cool time filler inbetween other games personally, well recomended

reviewText:
For a dollar it will give you good fun.

Pros:
Graphics
Music
Sound
Simple
Optimization

Cons:
Glitches that cause me to snap my wrists

The destructable walls dumb rubble at your feet which you cannot move through so you become trapped and die. You also cannot jump while in the rubble.

Shooting the laser causes really annoying slowdown which breaks the flow of the game.

You will randomly die for no reason. I died 3 times without enemies hitting me as I was simply running.

Its still decent for a buck though.
